channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Turkish Corruption Scandal Moves Closer to Erdogan
item.description: One of three ministers who resigned on Wednesday said the prime minister should resign as well, deepening the crisis.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: At the United States Embassy in Ankara, Turkey, on Monday, protesters denounced Ambassador Francis J. Ricciardone Jr.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Liu Ping’s Christmas in Jail
item.description: For Liu Ping, a Christian, and one of three campaigners for democracy and public disclosure of leaders’ assets detained and tried on charges their supporters say are false, this Christmas is very different.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Gillles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liu Ping is awaiting sentencing on charges related to her campaign for Chinese leaders to disclose their assets.

item.title: In Harshest Move Yet, Egypt Declares Muslim Brotherhood a Terrorist Group
item.description: The action is the harshest crackdown yet on the group, which emerged last year as the most successful group in democratic elections.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Pope Nods to Atheists in Christmas Message of Peace
item.description: Pope Francis, celebrating his first Christmas as the Roman Catholic leader, called on atheists to unite with believers of all religions and work for a peace that can spread across the world.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Pope Francis waved from the balcony of St. Peter’s Basilica at the Vatican after his Christmas blessing.

item.title: Political Fight in South Sudan Targets Civilians
item.description: The United Nations moves to nearly double peacekeeping forces in the young country, reeling from a politically motivated ethnic violence.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: About 12,000 members of the Nuer ethnic group in South Sudan have fled to a United Nations camp near the Juba airport.

item.title: TV Message By Snowden Says Privacy Still Matters
item.description: In a message broadcast on British television, Edward J. Snowden urged an end to mass surveillance, arguing that the electronic monitoring he has exposed surpasses anything imagined by George Orwell in “1984.”
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:credit: Channel 4, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: “Privacy matters, privacy is what allows us to determine who we are and who we want to be,” Edward Snowden said in a Christmas message.

item.title: Worshipers Targeted at Christmas Services in Baghdad
item.description: More than two dozen people were killed in when a car bomb exploded in a parking lot near a church, one of a series of attacks across Iraq.
item.dc:creator: By YASIR GHAZI

item.title: Rockets Fired by Taliban Hit U.S. Embassy in Kabul
item.description: The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack, which caused no casualties. Afghan officials said two other rockets hit elsewhere in Kabul, hurting three policemen.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and JAWAD SUKHANYAR
item.media:description: Afghans gathered near a crater from an attack targeting the United States Embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Wednesday.

item.title: Antigovernment Activist Is Beaten in Ukraine
item.description: As protests continued, Tetyana Chornovol, who helped expose the opulence of the presidential compound, was brutally attacked outside Kiev, the capital.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: In response to Tetyana Chornovol’s beating, several protest leaders called for picketing outside the Interior Ministry in Kiev on Wednesday.

item.title: China Investigates Vaccine Maker After Deaths of Infants
item.description: The government has suspended the use of millions of doses of a hepatitis B vaccine and inspectors have been sent to examine the drug maker’s facilities.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: Atheists, Work With Us for Peace, Pope Says on Christmas
item.description: Pope Francis, celebrating his first Christmas as Roman Catholic leader, on Wednesday called on atheists to unite with believers of all religions and work for "a homemade peace" that can spread across the world.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: Pope Francis waved from the balcony of St. Peter’s Basilica at the Vatican after his Christmas blessing.

item.title: Political Fight in South Sudan Targets Civilians
item.description: The crisis in South Sudan has broadened into a conflict in which longstanding ethnic divisions are fueling the violence and civilians are not accidental victims of the fighting.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: About 12,000 members of the Nuer ethnic group in South Sudan have fled to a United Nations camp near the Juba airport.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: December 25
item.description: Christmas is a national holiday in India and celebrated throughout much of the country.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Children dressed as Santa Claus played near a sand sculpture by the artist Sudarsan Pattnaik, at Golden Sea Beach in Puri. Christmas is a national holiday in India and celebrated throughout much of the country.

item.title: Change Comes Slowly for Bulgaria, Even With E.U. Membership
item.description: Protests continue for clean government six years after the country joined the European bloc, pointing to the prolonged process of change.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bulgarian students at a meeting at Sofia University on Dec. 6. The university is a center of the nation’s protest movement, which has already ousted one government.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Happy Birthday, Chairman Mao
item.description: With Mao’s 120th birthday approaching, some preparations are heating up while others have been scaled down, reflecting a desire at the top of the party for a more modest affair for a leader both revered and hated.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A girl poses next to a 3D painting of Mao Zedong at an exhibition in Binzhou, Shandong Province.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Detective Novelist Qiu Xiaolong on Chinese Corruption
item.description: The creator of Inspector Chen discusses political corruption, censorship, longing for good Chinese food in St. Louis and Bo Xilai not returning his table tennis paddle.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Dilip Vishwanat for The New York Times
item.media:description: Qiu Xiaolong's novels often explore the corruption that has sprung up amid China's one-party authoritarian rule.

item.title: Freed Russian Applies for Swiss Visa Allowing Travel in 26 Nations
item.description: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, a former oil tycoon and political opponent of President Vladimir V. Putin, has submitted his application to Switzerland for a three-month visa.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: The former oil tycoon and Kremlin critic Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky appearing at a news conference in Berlin on Sunday.

item.title: A New Jolt to Filipino Siblings Orphaned by a Typhoon
item.description: The disappearance of five siblings from a Tacloban evacuation center raised alarms about human trafficking, but they surfaced in an orphanage, reflecting a confused child protection system.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jomar Pascual, left; his sister, Jesper Anne, right; and their siblings at an orphanage in the Manila region to which they were taken from Tacloban.

item.title: Egyptian Officials Point at Islamist Group After Blast at Police Building
item.description: At least 15 people were killed in the bombing in the city of Mansoura, the deadliest such attack since President Mohamed Morsi was ousted in July.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:description: The body of one of those killed Tuesday by a car bomb in the northern Egyptian city of Mansoura was carried by mourners at a funeral later in the day.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Yemen: Parties Agree to Federalism
item.description: Yemeni political parties have signed a document pledging a “just solution” that would grant some autonomy to the once-independent south, the state news agency reported.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Floods and Landslides Kill 30
item.description: Heavy rains in Espírito Santo and Minas Gerais, two states in southeastern Brazil, have left at least 30 people dead and forced about 50,000 people from their homes.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Military Raid Destroys Villages and Kills Rebels, Witnesses Say
item.description: A military offensive in northeast Nigeria that killed more than 50 Islamist rebels also destroyed four villages and left corpses scattered in the bushes, witnesses said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Uruguay: Marijuana Becomes Legal
item.description: President José Mujica has signed into law the government’s plan to create a regulated, legal market for marijuana, his spokesman said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Oberhausen Journal: In Germany’s Rust Belt, a Polished but Ailing City
item.description: Oberhausen, crowned “Germany’s Detroit” because it has the country’s highest per capita debt, is long past its industrial glory days, but there are limits to how far the city will go to pare its cultural institutions.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:credit: Ben Kilb for The New York Times
item.media:description: Budget cuts in Oberhausen, Germany, shaved about $820 million off the city’s spending.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: It’s the Most Unknowable Time of the Year
item.description: For a Jewish kid, in Leningrad and then Queens, disguises were mystifying. They still are.
item.dc:creator: By GARY SHTEYNGART
